head.label:
Facts About James Weldon Johnson
By
Eartha M.M. White

body.p:
As I knew Mr. James Weldon Johnson, his father, Rev. James W. Johnson who
was a headwaiter at the St James Hotel, Jacksonville, Florida. Rev. James W.
Johnson was on vacation in New York City where he met Mrs. Barton and her daughter
who were also visiting in New York. He became very much interested in the daughter.
The Bartons extended an invitation to Reverend Johnson to visit their home in Nassau.
Here, he married the daughter and they were blessed with a girl baby who died in in
fancy.

Reverend Johnson purchased in Jacksonville, Florida the northeast corner of
Ward and Lee Streets (where the Firestone building is today). On the north end of
this property he erected a framed two story building, when completed he had his wife
and her mother, Mrs. Barton to come to Jacksonvile.

Mrs. Johnson formed a friendship with Miss Agnes Edwards who was like a sister
to her and was known as a foster sister. Both Mrs. Johnson and Miss. Edwards taught
in Stanton School30.352292 -81.673004.

Later there was born to them two sons, James Weldon and Rosemond. Both boys
attending Stanton under Dr. Culp. James Weldon finished Stanton under BPrincipal
Artrell. He became assistant to Mr. Artrell and when Mr. Artrell left the school he
became principal. It was during his administration Stanton30.352292 -81.673004 became the first Negro
high school in the country. He asked the school board for a raise of $75.00 in salary.
This was not granted, so he left Stanton30.352292 -81.673004.

He went to Atlanta to do further study. Here, he bacame interested in the
National Advancement of Colored People. He recieved many degrees and appointments.

Later he made his home in New York where he met Miss. Grace Nails, daughter
of Jack Nails and a friend of Eartha M. M. White. Grace not only became a wife but
a companion to Mr. Johnson. They traveled always together. They had no children.
She was ideal and loved everyone who was fortunate enough to meet her.

div.p:
Eartha M. M. White who was in school in New York City and Miss. Grace Nails were
girl friends long before she met Mr. Johnson. She had a wonderful disposition and
everyone admired her. It was upon the return home from a trip on a foggy morning
while Grace was a driving the car, she unfortunately ran into a train. Mr. Johnson
was killed. She never recovered from this shock.

Mr. Johnson was a wonderful writer and composer. One of the most outstanding
compositions was: "Lift Every Voice and Sing," known as the Negro National Anthem.
Mr. Johnson wrote the words while his brother wrote the music.

Mr. Graft, a millionaire of Syracuse, New York, who wanted to prove to the
world that Negroes could sing opera music as well as folk songs, financed for one
year a company known as the Oriental-America Opera Company. Madam Plato and Sidney
Woodard were the star singers. Mr. J. Rosemond Johnson was in charge of music. Two
Jacksonvillians were also selected: Earth M. M. White, a lyric saprano from the
National Conservatory of Music, Harry T. Burleigh, instructor and Estella Dorsey,
who had a wonderful contralto voice.

They opened at Palm Theatre on Broadway in New York City. This was the first
appearance of Negroes in that theatre. They traveled most of the cities in the
United States and abroad. This proved to be an over-whelming success. It was from
the Oriental-American Opera Company many other musical groups started. Millionaire
Graft was well pleased.

Lest we forget, his father was a Baptist preacher and a member of Bethal Baptist
Institutional Church. His mother, brother and James Weldon were members of Ebanezer
Methodist Episcopal Church and sang in the chior.
